questions:
A magnetic system of spins is at thermodynamic equilibrium at temperature $ T $. Let $ \mu $ be the magnetic moment of each spin; and let $ M $ be the mean magnetization per spin, so $-\mu < M < \mu$. The free energy per spin, for specified magnetization $ M $, is $ F(M) $.

(1) Compute the magnetization $ M $ as a function of external magnetic field strength $ B $, given that

$$
F(M) = \lambda \begin{cases} 
0, & |M/\mu| \leq 1/2, \\
(|M/\mu| - 1/2)^2, & 1 \geq |M/\mu| \geq 1/2 
\end{cases}
$$
where $\lambda$ is a constant.

(2) Suppose, instead, that someone gives you 

$$
F(M) = \lambda \left[ (M/\mu)^4 - (M/\mu)^2 \right],
$$
you should respond that this is unacceptable - this expression violates a fundamental convexity principle of thermodynamics. (a) State the principle. (b) Check it against the above expression. (c) Discuss, by at least one example, what would go wrong with thermodynamics if the principle is not satisfied.
llm_answers: For part $(1)$, we want to minimize the Free Energy functional $$f(\mathbf x)=E(\mathbf x)-TS,$$ where here our random variable takes on only two values $+/-$, i..e., either up or down ($\sigma=\pm$). We can write out explicitly these quantities using Stirling's approximation which says $$\log n! \approx n\log n-n.$$ This means first off that entropy has the form,$$\mathcal S=-k_B\{\rho_{up}\log[\rho_+]+\rho_{-}\log [\rho_-]\}.$$ Using now definitions from before such as magnetisation etc...we find after some algebra$$\mathcal G=A[(T-T_C)\frac{\langle s^z\rangle ^2}{N}+kT\log(2\cosh(H/kT))]-H\langle s^z\rangle .$$ Taking derivative w.r.t $\langle sz\rangle$(exercise), setting equal to zero and solving will give us exactly the equation mentioned already,(also notice how previous results come back!) , namely.$$\langle s^z\rangle =\tanh(\frac{H+T\Delta}{kT}).$$ Now its easy to see why ferromagnetism arises et cetera....as discussed earlier.(Its worthwhile thinking about also when the inequality holds!). To conclude I just wanted to quickly highlight another point often taught in undergraduate courses, but sadly passed over in most graduate ones I have seen. If time permits I may return to this later, however for those who wish to read more about it right now a good starting place ishere.
